answers.answer: It could be a UTI.It would really be best to bring a fresh urine sample to your vet for urinalysis.  First urine in the morning would be best but not necessary.The vulvar area contains the vagina and the urethra so it is difficult to distinguish a vaginal infection from a urinary tract infection.  If the urinalysis if negative for infection, she still may have a vaginal infection.Diabetes can give urine a sweat taste (due to glucose being lost through urine), and thus make it more desirable to ingest by your boxer.  Although it is unlikely, diabetes is a possibility, but this would be detected by urinalysis and than subsequent blood work.Or, your boxer may just want to eliminate an infection by "cleaning" your dog.  A urinalysis, vaginal exam and blood work, if necessary should determine the cause.

question: My girl Sasha is a recue dog and has been spayed.  My 7 yr old male boxer x is constantly following Sasha around licking her vulva and then drooling and "smacking his lips".  He displays the same behavior when she urinates, which he "samples".  I find it a disgusting habit.  She had a complete histerectomy, including overies, so it can't be hormonal.  Could it be a UTI?
title: could it be a UTI?
